memory-verse: Trust in the LORD with all your heart, And lean not on your own understanding; In all your ways acknowledge Him, And He shall direct your paths. (Proverbs 3:5-6)
prayer: Father in Jesus Name, I put my trust and hope in you. you alone are the truth. Thank you Lord.

title: OBEYING GOD WHEN IT HURTS
passage: 35 Therefore do not cast away your confidence, which has great reward. 36 For you have need of endurance, so that after you have done the will of God, you may receive the promise: 37 “For yet a little while, And He who is coming will come and will not tarry. 38 Now the just shall live by faith; But if anyone draws back, My soul has no pleasure in him.” 39 But we are not of those who draw back to perdition, but of those who believe to the saving of the soul. (Hebrews 10:35-39)
content: There was a situation that kept recurring in my life. I was being treated unfairly and my concerns were not taken seriously. Anytime I complained about the unfairness of it all, I was not even given the chance to complete my statements before I was judged based on unfinished statements and explanations. This went on for years and one day, I decided to take matters into my own hands. Obeying God was not a priority once I decided to take my revenge. I had concluded that God was not on my side and does not care about my suffering because He wasn’t handling the situation as I expected. On the day of my revenge, I overreacted, and my reaction was seen by all. Now the offended (me) looked like the offender! How I wished I had kept receiving the unfair treatment and insults and just waited for God to avenge me. Eventually, God fought for me, but I had cast away my confidence in Him before then. Endurance is a virtue that every believer must have. It will keep your testimony intact. Despite all your trials, it is very important that you remain confident that Jehovah sees and will surely vindicate you. He is the “rewarder of those who diligently seek Him.”
application: When you are being treated unfairly; do what is right; don’t destroy others just to get even. Most importantly, trust God.
memory-verse: Trust in the LORD with all your heart, And lean not on your own understanding; In all your ways acknowledge Him, And He shall direct your paths. (Proverbs 3:5-6)
prayer: O God in the Name of Jesus, give me strength in adversity to do the right thing.

title: ANSWERED PRAYER
passage: 1 There was a man named Elkanah who lived in Ramah in the region of Zuph in the hill country of Ephraim. He was the son of Jeroham, son of Elihu, son of Tohu, son of Zuph, of Ephraim. 2 Elkanah had two wives, Hannah and Peninnah. Peninnah had children, but Hannah did not. 3 Each year Elkanah would travel to Shiloh to worship and sacrifice to the LORD of Heaven’s Armies at the Tabernacle. The priests of the LORD at that time were the two sons of Eli—Hophni and Phinehas. 4 On the days Elkanah presented his sacrifice, he would give portions of the meat to Peninnah and each of her children. 5 And though he loved Hannah, he would give her only one choice portion because the LORD had given her no children. 6 So Peninnah would taunt Hannah and make fun of her because the LORD had kept her from having children. 7 Year after year it was the same—Peninnah would taunt Hannah as they went to the Tabernacle. Each time, Hannah would be reduced to tears and would not even eat. (1 Samuel 1: 1-7)
content: If I ask if you have experienced antagonism before, it is likely that you will say yes. If I ask how you felt about the experience, you will likely say that it is not an enjoyable experience. However, antagonism can work out for our good sometimes. In the Biblical example of Hannah and Peninnah, Hannah had no children but Peninnah oppressed Hannah because of her barrenness. Each year, Peninnah, Hannah and their husband, Elkanah, travel to Shiloh to worship and sacrifice to God at the tabernacle. Peninnah would taunt Hannah and make fun of her till she is reduced to tears and not eat there. When we study the bible further, we realize that Hannah’s barrenness was not by accident. It was God that kept Hannah from having children! One year at Shiloh, Hannah rose up to Peninnah’s challenge and despite her anguished heart, prayed to God and made a vow. This led to her answered prayers. Sometimes challenges draw us into a deeper and closer walk with God. Most times, challenges reveal our humanity and lead us into total dependence on God, where we tell God, “If He doesn’t answer our prayers, no one can”. Peninnah’s antagonism of Hannah led Hannah to pray to God in a different way than her norm. It led her to press into God and she was rewarded with her son, Samuel. After this time, Peninnah’s taunts became irrelevant in Hannah’s life. Press into God despite the antagonism you are feeling or the naysayers. Cast your cares on God for He cares for you. May God visit you and meet your needs in Jesus name.
application: I will not let antagonism lead me away from God. I will use those challenging opportunities to seek God more.
memory-verse: And we boast in the hope of the glory of God.  Not only so, but we also glory in our sufferings, because we know that suffering produces perseverance; perseverance, character; and character, hope. And hope does not put us to shame. (Romans 5:2-5)
prayer: Lord, I ignore every antagonism and seek your face today. Meet my needs, O Lord, as I press into you in Jesus name

title: TIDE TURNING
passage: 4 Then Joseph said to his brothers, “Come close to me.” When they had done so, he said, “I am your brother Joseph, the one you sold into Egypt! 5 And now, do not be distressed and do not be angry with yourselves for selling me here, because it was to save lives that God sent me ahead of you. 6 For two years now there has been famine in the land, and for the next five years there will be no plowing and reaping.7 But God sent me ahead of you to preserve for you a remnant on earth and to save your lives by a great deliverance.8 “So then, it was not you who sent me here, but God. He made me father to Pharaoh, lord of his entire household and ruler of all Egypt. (Genesis 45:4-8)
content: Many people who have dealt with antagonism knows that it requires a lot of wisdom and maturity to prevent situations from escalating. Antagonism means “to oppose or work against.” It can be experienced within a family, work, church, friends, etc. The example from the Bible that comes to mind is Jacob’s family. Jacob loved Joseph, one of his sons, more than his other sons and this was obvious to them. They hated him because of this fact. In fact, they hated him so much that when the opportunity to get rid of him presented itself, they were so eaten up by hate that they sold him despite the obvious hurt to the family especially their father. They even contemplated killing him before concluding on the decision to sell him! Note that the reason they hate him is not because he was a bad brother. It was a factor beyond Jacob’s control. Sometimes people may be antagonistic towards you for reasons beyond your control. Other times, the glory ahead is obvious that people might try to waylay you. In Joseph’s story, he went through Pharaoh’s palace to prison to becoming a prime minister.  God was faithful to him despite the challenges. No one can stop God’s plan for you. It might be delayed but it will surely come to pass. God surpassed Joseph’s expectation that even his brothers could not believe their eyes when they saw he had become the prime minister. Though they eventually apologized to Joseph, God had already vindicated Joseph. There are many lessons to learn from this story. First, people don’t need legitimate reason to dislike you. They may dislike you for factors beyond your control, but as much as it depends on you, be at peace with all people. Secondly, understand that no one can stop God’s plan for you. They can try but they will fail. The dreams that Joseph’s brothers antagonized him for led to his breakthrough in Pharaoh’s palace. Pray against every delay in God’s plan for you through antagonism. Thirdly, let God vindicate you like He did for Joseph. Do not repay evil with evil. In all things, demonstrate the character of Christ and extend forgiveness to others who knowingly or unknowingly sin against you.
application: I will demonstrate the character of Christ and forgive others who sin against me.
memory-verse: And we boast in the hope of the glory of God.  Not only so, but we also glory in our sufferings, because we know that suffering produces perseverance; perseverance, character; and character, hope. And hope does not put us to shame. (Romans 5:2-5)
prayer: Lord, use everything the enemy meant for evil in my life, for good in Jesus name.

title: THE SUPPLANTER
passage: 10 This son was our ancestor Isaac. When he married Rebekah, she gave birth to twins.11 But before they were born, before they had done anything good or bad, she received a message from God. (This message shows that God chooses people according to his own purposes; 12 he calls people, but not according to their good or bad works.) She was told, “Your older son will serve your younger son.” 13 In the words of the Scriptures, “I loved Jacob, but I rejected Esau.” (Romans 9:10-13)
content: In the Bible, Jacob was Esau’s twin. The name Jacob means supplanter among other meanings. A supplanter is one who tries to take another’s rightful place. When their mother, Rebekah, got pregnant, the babies fought in her womb. She inquired about this from God and God told her that they would be rival nations. When they were born, Jacob, the younger son, had his hand grasping Esau’s heel. In the course of their lives, Jacob tricked Esau into giving away his birthright. And when it came time for their father, Isaac, to bless the eldest son, Jacob again with the help of his mother, took his brother’s blessing. After Jacob stole his brother’s blessing, Esau vowed to kill him. Though Jacob was the supplanter, God loved him and showed him favor. Even before He was born, it was told to their mother, Rebekah that the older son, Esau will serve the younger, Jacob. Though, God knew how conniving Jacob was, he had great plans for Him. It was the antagonism with his brother that God used to draw him closer to Himself. After Jacob stole Esau’s blessing, Rebekah sent Jacob away to avoid a collision with Esau.  On the way at Bethel, Jacob encountered God. He had a dream where he saw a stairway that reached from earth to heaven. He also saw the angels of God going up and down the stairway. At the top of the stairway, He saw God who spoke to him about his descendants, future and plans for him. This is one of the many encounters that Jacob had with God and it was when he was running away from his brother. Though Jacob was a master manipulator, He met his match in God. God can use anyone or anything to draw people closer. The bible says that He has good plans for everyone. If we would surrender to Him totally, even in our sins, He can transform us and use our lives for His glory.
application: I will allow God to transform my weaknesses into strength.
memory-verse: And we boast in the hope of the glory of God.  Not only so, but we also glory in our sufferings, because we know that suffering produces perseverance; perseverance, character; and character, hope. And hope does not put us to shame. (Romans 5:2-5)
prayer: Lord, use my life for your glory. Turn my weaknesses into strength in Jesus name.

title: PERSECUTED
passage: 4 Even before he made the world, God loved us and chose us in Christ to be holy and without fault in his eyes. 5 God decided in advance to adopt us into his own family by bringing us to himself through Jesus Christ. This is what he wanted to do, and it gave him great pleasure. 6 So we praise God for the glorious grace he has poured out on us who belong to his dear Son.[b] 7 He is so rich in kindness and grace that he purchased our freedom with the blood of his Son and forgave our sins. 8 He has showered his kindness on us, along with all wisdom and understanding (Ephesians 1: 4-8)
content: I remember being chastised as a child in class. My personality is usually quiet but whenever, the “class” makes noise, everyone gets punished. Of course, I felt the unfairness of the situation but usually the teacher does not allow explanations. Even if you could explain, you don’t dare mention names since you got persecuted for being a tattle-tale. One of our biggest examples in the area of the persecution was our Lord and Savior, Jesus Christ. In our chapter today, we learned that before God made the world, He loved us and chose us to be holy and without fault in His eyes. He decided in advance to adopt us into His family by reconciling us to Himself through Jesus Christ. Despite this love, Jesus who is God did not have an easy time convincing humanity of His true purpose. All His intention towards humankind was good, yet, he was often persecuted especially by the “teachers of the law.” The bible also recorded that in his hometown, due to familiarity of the people with him and his family, he only did a few miracles because of the people’s unbelief. They did not believe him! Persecution is not easy to bear especially when you are being persecuted for something that you know is right. It is possible that you are being persecuted like Christ or the sake of Christ or the Gospel. First, know that the Bible says that in this world, we will have trouble but do not fear because He has overcome the world. Secondly, know that there is a reward in Heaven for you. There is nothing that you suffered for His name that you will not be rewarded for in Heaven. In Matthew, Jesus taught the disciples that “blessed are they that are persecuted for righteousness ’sake, for theirs is the kingdom of Heaven.” Thirdly, it is for a short time because nothing lasts forever, even persecution. Jesus went through it and more for you. When you were undeserving, He went through the crucifixion and died for your sake. As you go through persecution, rejoice in the Lord because to be persecuted means you are taking a stand for Christ. Remain true to God and hold onto Him. There is a great reward waiting for you.
application: I will be bold and not to give up my faith in the face of persecution.
memory-verse: And we boast in the hope of the glory of God.  Not only so, but we also glory in our sufferings, because we know that suffering produces perseverance; perseverance, character; and character, hope. And hope does not put us to shame. (Romans 5:2-5)
prayer: Lord, I receive the boldness and strength to go through persecution with a victorious attitude knowing that you are my rewarder.

title: RESTORATION
passage: 8 Eventually, a new king came to power in Egypt who knew nothing about Joseph or what he had done. 9 He said to his people, “Look, the people of Israel now outnumber us and are stronger than we are. 10 We must make a plan to keep them from growing even more. If we don’t, and if war breaks out, they will join our enemies and fight against us. Then they will escape from the country.11 So the Egyptians made the Israelites their slaves. They appointed brutal slave drivers over them, hoping to wear them down with crushing labor. They forced them to build the cities of Pithom and Rameses as supply centers for the king. 12 But the more the Egyptians oppressed them, the more the Israelites multiplied and spread, and the more alarmed the Egyptians became. 13 So the Egyptians worked the people of Israel without mercy. 14 They made their lives bitter, forcing them to mix mortar and make bricks and do all the work in the fields. They were ruthless in all their demands.  (Exodus 1: 8-14)
content: All over the world, you hear about the fight against injustice. This injustice could be towards a targeted group of people such as minorities, ethnic groups, religious groups, etc. In the United States, there are many different movements fighting against injustice. This has been since the beginning except things were handled differently then. A Biblical example is the Israelites in the Bible. The Israelites were Egyptian slaves. They became slaves because the Egyptians feared that the Israelites would over power them in a war due to their massive numbers. However, the more the Egyptians oppressed the Israelites, the more the Israelites multiplied and spread. In their alarm, the Egyptians worked the Israelites harder, hoping to break them. However, God of Heaven heard the cries of the Israelites and rose to their aid. There are many lessons in this chapter, but I will elucidate a few. First, the Egyptians made the Israelites slaves out of fear. The Israelites didn’t particularly do anything wrong. It is just the plan of the enemy to keep them beneath them, though, God favored them.  Secondly, the Israelites knew to cry out to God in their oppression and He heard them. Their deliverance required faith in God on their part. Despite what their eyes could see, they had to believe God and take Him at His word that He would deliver them. Thirdly, their deliverance was not based on their ability but on their total dependence on God. They had no power or wealth of their own. Also, they did not have the army or chariots like the Egyptians. Lastly, at the Red Sea, when it seemed like everything was at its worst was when God was at His best. God is a good God. Cry out to Him like the Israelites did if you are going through any oppressive situation today. Know that you are not alone. He will hear You when you call on Him today.
application: I will ask God for deliverance from any oppressive situation that I am in today.
memory-verse: And we boast in the hope of the glory of God.  Not only so, but we also glory in our sufferings, because we know that suffering produces perseverance; perseverance, character; and character, hope. And hope does not put us to shame. (Romans 5:2-5)
prayer: Lord, you are my deliverer. Please deliver me from every oppression in my life.

title: NEVER GIVE UP
passage: 1Now there was a famine in the land besides the previous famine in Abraham’s time and Isaac went to Abimelek king of the Philistines in Gerar. 2 The LORD appeared to Isaac and said, “Do not go down to Egypt;live in the land where I tell you to live. 3 Stay in this land for a while, and I will be with you and will bless you. For to you and your descendants I will give all these lands and will confirm the oath I swore to your father Abraham. 4 I will make your descendants as numerous as the stars in the sky and will give them all these lands, and through your offspring  all nations on earth will be blessed,5 because Abraham obeyed me and did everything I required of him, keeping my commands, my decrees and my instructions.” 6 So Isaac stayed in Gerar. (Genesis 26:1-6)
content: Isaac is one of the patriarchs of the Bible. He was the promised son of Abraham and Sarah. After a famine struck the land where he lived, He moved to Gerar. God gave Isaac specific instructions about living in Gerar. While living as a foreigner there, God promised to be with Him and bless him. He was also promised his father’s blessings. In Gerar, God blessed Isaac exceedingly that he became a rich man whose wealth grew. This led to jealousy by the Philistines who filled his wells with dirt in sabotage. Finally, he was sent away by their king because he had become “too powerful for them.” He went away and dug many wells that resulted in controversy and he eventually had to leave them behind. While reading this story, one of the first questions that came to my mind was “didn’t God tell Isaac to stay in Gerar and that He would bless him if He did? If so, why was there so much animosity with the people of the land that he had to repeat his efforts to be successful? Why couldn’t God send him to another place where it would be easier?” Sometimes, we make the mistake of thinking that if God makes you a promise; there will be no challenge in accomplishing it. As we can see, though Isaac was challenged many times, he did not give up. Just like his father before him, Abraham, he believed God who promised to bless him in a foreign land and give him his father’s blessings. After seeing the tenacity of Isaac and God’s workings in Isaac’s life, the King of the Philistines was forced to reckon that God was with Isaac and made a peace treaty with him. What has God promised you that seems so long in coming? Does it look like your efforts are not coming together quickly? This does not mean that God did not speak to you. It also does not mean God has abandoned you or that you are a failure. A righteous man may fall many times, but he will rise up again with God’s help. It is not too late for you to rise up again. God may want to build you up before you possess some of His promises to you. Go back to God in prayer for more leading or clarification if you need to but don’t give up on God or His promise for your life. God will help you today.
application: I won’t give up on God’s plan and purpose for my life.
memory-verse: And we boast in the hope of the glory of God.  Not only so, but we also glory in our sufferings, because we know that suffering produces perseverance; perseverance, character; and character, hope. And hope does not put us to shame. (Romans 5:2-5)
prayer: Lord, please help me to fulfill your plans and purpose for my life. I won’t give up so quickly on you in Jesus name.

title: UNITY
passage: 1As a prisoner for the Lord, then, I urge you to live a life worthy of the calling you have received. 2 Be completely humble and gentle; be patient, bearing with one another in love. 3 Make every effort to keep the unity of the Spirit through the bond of peace. 4 There is one body and one Spirit, just as you were called to one hope when you were called; 5 one Lord, one faith, one baptism; 6 one God and Father of all, who is over all and through all and in all (Ephesians 1:1-6)
content: An antonym of antagonism or opposition is unity. Unity is a very integral part of being a Christian. All through this week, we learnt about opposition and antagonism among brethren, family members, brothers, wives and even nations. Just as antagonism and opposition is damaging, unity is very essential in the body of Christ. Unity can be defined as “harmony, agreement, or oneness of mind and purpose. One example of unity in the Bible can be seen in the Upper Room where the apostles gathered on the Day of Pentecost. They were together in one accord when the Holy Spirit came down. Now, we all have the Holy Spirit residing in each of us. However, in Acts Chapter 2, it was when the apostles gathered together in unity that the Holy Spirit came down in their midst. Another example was in the Tower of Babel when the whole world had one language and a common speech. Even God said in the book of Genesis of the people, “If as one people speaking the same language they have begun to do this, then nothing they plan to do will be impossible for them.” God knew that in unity of purpose, men can accomplish much. There are a few takeaways from today’s message.  First, do not forsake the assembly of fellow believers. Pray with the corporate body of Christ. It will build you up as iron sharpens iron. Secondly, pray in your family together. It will foster togetherness and keep the family flourishing as your prayers are answered. Thirdly, look for a fellow brother or sister to agree together in prayer when needed and see that stubborn mountain leveled before you. God is the same yesterday, today and forever. In unity, you can experience His mighty power and wonders.
application: I will unite with fellow Christians to pray and see God move mightily in our midst.
memory-verse: And we boast in the hope of the glory of God.  Not only so, but we also glory in our sufferings, because we know that suffering produces perseverance; perseverance, character; and character, hope. And hope does not put us to shame. (Romans 5:2-5)
prayer: Lord, as I join others to pray, answer my prayers speedily in Jesus name

title: A COMFORTER IN NEED
passage: 10 “Rejoice with Jerusalem, And be glad with her, all you who love her; Rejoice for joy with her, all you who mourn for her; 11 That you may feed and be satisfied With the consolation of her bosom, That you may drink deeply and be delighted With the abundance of her glory.” 12 For thus says the LORD: “Behold, I will extend peace to her like a river, And the glory of the Gentiles like a flowing stream. Then you shall feed; On her sides shall you be carried, And be dandled on her knees. 13 As one whom his mother comforts, So I will comfort you; And you shall be comforted in Jerusalem.” (Isaiah 66:10-13)
content: Today’s scripture reading reveals one of the many qualities of a mother: a comforter. But what exactly does that entail? What does it truly mean to be a comforter to our children? Webster’s dictionary defines comfort in two ways. The first explains that a comforter provides consolation, especially in times of loss or suffering. Many of us are familiar with this aspect of comfort. The second definition, my favorite, explains that a comforter provides hope and strength. Neither consoling or encouraging are easy tasks, yet as mothers we do so for our children time and time again—when they fall learning to ride a bike or as they navigate through relationships with friends or significant others. But like our children, we are mere humans. Life happens and there comes a time when even mothers become the ones in need of comfort. So what happens when the comforter needs comforting? In the Scripture reading, God promises to comfort you and me. He is our Comforter. We can look to Him in times of trouble for consolation and encouragement. In John 14:18 (KJV), Jesus promises that He will not leave us comfortless and so the Holy Spirit was given to us even for this purpose. The Greek word for comfort (parakletos) means “called to one’s side”. How great is it to know that God is on our side? Even as comforters we have our very own Comforter.
application: In times of tribulation, look to God as the source of your comfort and strength, recognizing that He is on your side to aid you.
memory-verse: “For I, the Lord your God, will hold your right hand, saying to you, ‘Fear not, I will help you.’” (Isaiah 41:13)
prayer: Lord, comfort me in my time of need. Give me strength where I am weak.

title: A REWARD FOR KINDNESS
passage: 16 A kindhearted woman gains honor, but ruthless men gain only wealth. 17 Those who are kind benefit themselves, but the cruel bring ruin on themselves. 18 A wicked person earns deceptive wages, but the one who sows righteousness reaps a sure reward. (Proverbs 11:16-18)
content: Motherhood is wonderful. I think every mother would agree that there are rewards that come along with it, like seeing your children smile when you’re able to give them something they want and provide beyond their basic needs. I sometimes sit and watch my two young children play together. No television on. No phone in my hand or computer on my lap. I just sit and watch them laugh and play and it brings me such joy. Then there are times when I am really busy and it feels as if there is no time to sit and watch and be still. Sometimes I get stressed out and tired. I find that in the busy times, the stressful and tired times, that I’m a little less patient, a little quicker to anger, and sometimes even a little mean. Can you identify with my experience? Today’s verse is a good reminder that the woman who gains honor (or respect) is the one who is kind-hearted—in both the calm and busy times. We can infer then that an easy way to lose honor or respect is to be unkind. I’m sure we can agree that children learn from everything they see. So when they see us act unkind in difficult times, it teaches them that it’s okay for them to do so as well. The truth is that we should be kind at all times. Maybe you have experienced disrespectfulness lately, from your children or someone else. We should consider how our own words and actions might be contributing to such disrespect.
application: Reflect on how you treat your children and others in various situations. Focus on being kind-hearted even when it isn’t easy.
memory-verse: “For I, the Lord your God, will hold your right hand, saying to you, ‘Fear not, I will help you.’” (Isaiah 41:13)
prayer: Prayer: Father uproot every unkindness in me. Help me to be kind at all times and to all people.

title: SELF-MADE MOM
passage: “Therefore humble yourselves under the mighty hand of God, that He may exalt you in due time, casting all your cares upon Him, for He cares for you.” (1 Peter 5:6-7)
content: Entering motherhood has been one of the most humbling experiences of my life. It has challenged me physically, spiritually, mentally, and definitely emotionally. In this (fairly) new season I have learned that I don’t “have it all together”, that I am still a work in progress. Not too long ago, it was very discouraging to me that I wasn’t a perfect mom. It felt like other moms around me had it figured out and I was still trying to learn to adjust to all my new responsibilities. I felt alone in how I was coping with entering into motherhood and alone in my duties as a mother. As I read the scripture reading for today, I realized I didn’t have to do things all by myself and trying to do so was an insult to God because I was trying to be self-reliant. Many pastors have shared with me that God created us to be dependent on God and interdependent on other humans. So, to humble ourselves under God means to dismiss self-reliance and replace it with a God-reliance, to be fully dependent on Him. You have heard there’s no such thing as a self-made millionaire. Well, there’s also no such thing as a selfmade mom. We can’t do it on our own because we’re not supposed to. We weren’t created that way. We must cast our cares on the Lord to be able to do the things He has called us to do. How great is it to know that though the responsibility is ours, we are His responsibility?
application: God did not entrust you with responsibility and walk away. He is always there for you so depend on Him because He cares.
memory-verse: “For I, the Lord your God, will hold your right hand, saying to you, ‘Fear not, I will help you.’” (Isaiah 41:13)
prayer: Lord forgive me for trying to do things on my own. I recognize that I need you and ask that you help me with all I have to do.

title: THE CYCLE OF FEAR
passage: “Have I not commanded you? Be strong and of good courage; do not be afraid, nor be dismayed, for the Lord your God is with you wherever you go.” (Joshua 1:9)
content: God wants us to walk by faith, not by fear. Fear is a weapon of the devil. It is a tool used for our destruction. It is often used in combination with distraction, which is the first step in the cycle of fear. The devil distracts us from our relationship with God, such as through separating us from prayer. Paul tells us, “Do not be anxious about anything, but in everything by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known to God. And the peace of God, which surpasses all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus” (Philippians 4:6-7 ESV). So the devil distracts us by convincing us we are too busy, too tired, and so forth to pray. The scripture tells us that peace is a protective covering for our minds, and by extension, our thoughts. So the devil is able to break down our protective peace covering by preventing us from going to God in prayer. This is the second step in the cycle of fear. The devil steals our peace. Once our peace is gone, our minds are now unprotected from the tricks of the devil. This leads to the third step in the cycle of fear: capture our sight. I’m not talking about our physical sight, but rather our mind and thoughts. When we stop praying (which we are commanded to do without ceasing), our focus is no longer on the God who is able, and the peace we have in knowing the power of the God we serve is lost. The devil knows that if he has your mind, he has your focus. “Finally, brothers, whatever is true, whatever is honorable, whatever is just, whatever is pure, whatever is lovely, whatever is commendable, if there is any excellence, if there is anything worthy of praise, think about these things. What you have learned and received and heard and seen in me—practice these things, and the God of peace will be with you” (Philippians 4:8-9, ESV). The fourth and final cycle of fear is to control our actions. If the enemy has control of our focus (turning our eyes toward the problem and away from the problem-solver) then he can stifle the action God is calling us to take. One of these actions is prayer and so the cycle begins again.
application: Ask yourself: What am I imagining? What am I envisioning with my mind? Where is my focus? Break the cycle of fear by continuously going to God in prayer and making your requests known to Him.
memory-verse: “For I, the Lord your God, will hold your right hand, saying to you, ‘Fear not, I will help you.’” (Isaiah 41:13)
prayer: Lord, redirect my thoughts toward you and the promises of your word. Let your peace protect my mind and may the enemy never gain access again in the mighty name of Jesus

title: GOD-ESTEEM
passage: 5 Keep your life free from love of money, and be content with what you have, for he has said, “I will never leave you nor forsake you.” 6 So we can confidently say, “The Lord is my helper; I will not fear; what can man do to me?” (Hebrews 13:56)
content: The word that stands out to me in this passage is “confidently.” To have confidence in something or someone means that you have certainty and assurance that you can rely on that person or thing. As a child, and even into early adulthood, I struggled with very low self-esteem and, as a result, had a lot of doubt in myself and my capabilities. Simply put, I didn’t think I was worth much. I noticed that even after I accepted Christ as my Savior and gave my life to Him all of my problems did not cease. In fact, I carried the baggage of low self-esteem and self-doubt into my Christian identity. I still didn’t see myself the way God sees me, so I couldn’t confidently say that He was my Helper. I didn’t think I was worthy of His help. So often times I rejected it. But the good news is that God did not call us to be worthy, only to be willing. You have heard the phrase: God does not call the equipped, but He equips the called. So also, God does not call those worthy of His help, only those who are willing to receive it.
application: Put aside self-esteem for God-esteem. Stop waiting to be worthy, instead be willing to receive help from the Lord.
memory-verse: “For I, the Lord your God, will hold your right hand, saying to you, ‘Fear not, I will help you.’” (Isaiah 41:13)
prayer: Father help me to see myself the way you see me, as light and salt, and grant me the grace to accept you as my Helper.

title: ORDINARY HELP
passage: 11Then the Lord said to Elijah, ‘Go, stand in front of Me on the mountain. I, the Lord, will pass by you.’ Then a very strong wind blew. The wind cause the mountains to break apart. It broke large rocks in front of the Lord. But that wind was not the Lord. After that wind, there was an earthquake. But that earthquake was not the Lord. After the earthquake, there was a fire. But that fire was not the Lord. After the fire, there was a quiet, gentle voice.” (I Kings 19:11-12)
content: In the Christian community, we can sometimes get hung up on the miraculous works of God. We hear many sermons on the miracles Jesus performed and receive encouragement that we ourselves will experience our own miracles. I believe that we all will in Jesus’ name. Sometimes, however, we miss the ordinary ways God helps us because we are so focused on receiving a miracle. In the scripture reading, Elijah had just escaped from Jezebel who sought to kill him. At this time, Elijah was the only prophet of God left. Israel had forsaken God’s covenant yet again. So, in his prayer, Elijah was complaining to God about Israel and how he’s the only prophet of God left. He didn’t know what else to do—to the point that he asked God to take his life. I imagine Elijah must have been asking himself why is he in this situation? How did he get to this point? It would seem to any of us that Elijah needed a miracle, but God thought otherwise (Isaiah 55:9). Based on the scripture reading, God did not come in the form of wind, or earthquake, or fire, but He came as a quiet, gentle voice. In other words, God didn’t take extraordinary measures to answer Elijah’s prayer, He simply answered in the ordinary. The scripture goes on to tell us that Elijah heard the gentle voice of God. Can you hear His gentle voice? Does your desire for a miracle overpower your ability to see all the ways in which God works?
application: Take time to reflect on the ordinary ways in which God works in your life.
memory-verse: “For I, the Lord your God, will hold your right hand, saying to you, ‘Fear not, I will help you.’” (Isaiah 41:13)
prayer: Lord, I thank you for all the ways you help me. Teach me to see your ways more clearly.

title: SILIENT HELP
passage: 9 Let love be without hypocrisy. Abhor what is evil. Cling to what is good. 10 Be kindly affectionate to one another with brotherly love, in honor giving preference to one another; 11 not lagging in diligence, fervent in spirit, serving the Lord; 12 rejoicing in hope, patient in tribulation, continuing steadfastly in prayer. (Romans 12:9-12)
content: We live in a very fast-paced, instant, ready to-go society. We can order food online or in an app so that it’s already prepared when we get to the restaurant, so, no more waiting in lines during the lunch rush hour. We can skip adding items to our online shopping carts with 1-click ordering on Amazon. We can even ask Google or Alexa to define a word for us without having to take time looking it up in the dictionary. We have been spoiled to get things we want when we want them (or at least very soon afterwards). It’s no wonder we pray to God and expect an answer immediately. We’re so used to cutting out the waiting process in so many other areas of our lives that we try to do the same thing with prayer. We try to eliminate or at least reduce God’s response time in hopes of getting answers or help from God a little (or let’s be honest, a lot) faster. Yet there are benefits to waiting on God, such as teaching us that we need to depend on Him, developing patience (a fruit of the Spirit) in us, helping us to exercise faith, and teaching us to be still, even in a fast-paced world. When we try to eliminate the waiting process by taking matters into our own hands, we’re actually hurting ourselves because we no longer experience the benefits that come with waiting. So, God’s silence is not Him ignoring us, it’s actually another way He helps us before He answers our prayers.
application: As you wait on God, experience the help He is already offering.
memory-verse: “For I, the Lord your God, will hold your right hand, saying to you, ‘Fear not, I will help you.’” (Isaiah 41:13)
prayer: God, help me to develop the fruit of patience as I wait on you. Help me to not mistake your silence for disregard.

title: STRIVING FOR HOLINESS
passage: 17 “Don’t you see that whatever enters the mouth goes into the stomach and then out of the body? 18 But the things that come out of a person’s mouth come from the heart, and these defile them. 19 For out of the heart come evil thoughts— murder, adultery, sexual immorality, theft, false testimony, slander. 20 These are what defile a person; but eating with unwashed hands does not defile them.” (Matthew 15:17-20)
content: God's nature is holy. He wants holiness in our lives and hearts. It is easy to project "righteousness", but God sees us for who we really are on the inside. We must inwardly cleanse ourselves because as Christians we are called to be holy and blameless (Ephesians 1:4), but we cannot be those things if we are constantly defiling ourselves by the way we think and speak. When we walk closely with God we will develop the fruit of the spirit but that can’t happen without a genuine conversion and transformation of the heart. Christ didn’t die to save us from sin alone, He came so that we might become holy. Although it’s a lifelong process there are few things we can do in our everyday lives that will aid us on our journey towards sanctification. We must make a conscious effort to pursue holiness. If we truly love God, we will commit to making holiness one of our many goals in life. Yielding to the Holy Spirit, the Holy Spirit will reveal our sins, so we can recognize them and choose to turn away from them. It will also shine a light on scripture so that we can understand the meaning and how to apply it to our lives. There can’t be holiness without Obedience. Seek improvement, not perfection. At times we as Christians don’t strive towards holiness because it appears as an impossible standard. Our lack of perfection should push us to continually trust in God to meet His goal for us and to rely on his strength. We also must remember that God is the one who sanctifies us. And lastly, we as believers are to be holy not because we want to gain the love of Christ but because we already have love in Christ. We are loved because He loved us first and the best way to show that love is by striving to become holy, because He is holy.
application: There’s absolutely nothing we can do without God, so when faced with what seems like an impossible task ask him for the strength, ask him to teach you to do things his way.
memory-verse: But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, forbearance, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness and self-control. Against such things there is no law. (Galatians 5:22-23)
prayer: Lord, in everything that I do help me and teach me to be as holy as you are.

title: BEWARE OF HYPOCRISY
passage: 13 “Woe to you, teachers of the law and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You shut the door of the kingdom of heaven in people’s faces. You yourselves do not enter, nor will you let those enter who are trying to. 15 “Woe to you, teachers of the law and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You travel over land and sea to win a single convert, and when you have succeeded, you make them twice as much a child of hell as you are. (Matthew 23:13-15)
content: The religious leaders during the time of Jesus’ earthly ministry, also known as the Pharisees, were obsessed with the law. They were well versed in the scripture and passionate about following every letter of the Law. However, in adhering to the law they searched for loopholes that would allow them to defy the spirit behind the law. Also, they showed no compassion toward their brethren and overly expressed their “spirituality” just to be praised by those around them. It was their hypocrisy that kept them from having genuine fellowship with God. Although Jesus never outright condemned them for their behavior, He did point out that ’justice and mercy and faithfulness.’ are more important than pursuing perfection. Jesus made it obvious that there wasn’t a problem with the law but with the way the Pharisees executed it. The Bible calls hypocrisy a sin, in which there are two forms, that of declaring belief in something and then acting contrary to that belief, and that of looking down on others when we ourselves are far from perfect. The word ‘hypocrite’ came into English from the Greek word ‘hypokrites’, which means “an actor” or “a stage player.” As followers of Christ we should be consistent with what we believe and who we claim to be in Christ. Acting is best left for the stage, not real life.
application: Think twice then act. Take a second and think about what you’re about to say or do and ask yourself if it’s something that contradicts who you say you believe in.
memory-verse: But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, forbearance, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness and self-control. Against such things there is no law. (Galatians 5:22-23)
prayer: Father let my life be a reflection of who you are, so that others may see you in me and draw close to you.

title: OWNING YOUR PEACE
passage: If it is possible, as far as it depends on you, live at peace with everyone. (Romans 12:18)
content: At some point in our lives we have dealt with someone who insists on making our lives extremely difficult. Such people carry a toxic character trait. Toxic people will blame everyone but themselves for their problems; they might even put the blame on you. As much as they may love to blame their pain on you, you have to realize it is not about you. They have issues that they don’t know how to deal with, so they lash out. The Bible says, “If it is possible, as far as it depends on you, live at peace with everyone.” Notice how the verse say ‘IF” not ‘IT IS”. Sometimes in life it is not always possible to live at peace with everyone. There are just some people that no matter what you do they will always go out of their way to make everyone around them uncomfortable; no matter how nice you are to them they are still going to be mean to you. And the second part of that verse says, “as far it depends on you”. That means you must do your best to preserve peace. Don’t start fights. Don’t stir up trouble over things that aren’t even important. How do we live peaceably? Well, we can’t live a peaceful life unless we are at peace with God. Peace is found in salvation. Jesus is the only way to be at peace with God. He alone is the Prince of peace. Peace is not the absence of trouble, we have to constantly work at having peace in our hearts, which will in turn make our homes better; make the church better and society better.
application: It can be hard to be the “bigger” person but as Christians we have to turn the other cheek and keep things as peaceful as possible.
memory-verse: But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, forbearance, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness and self-control. Against such things there is no law. (Galatians 5:22-23)
prayer: Lord, teach me how to deal with difficult people and help me to bring peace into the life of those around me.

title: THE POWER OF THE TONGUE
passage: Do not let any unwholesome talk come out of your mouths, but only what is helpful for building others up according to their needs, that it may benefit those who listen. (Ephesians 4:29)
content: There is so much power in the tongue. Through the use of the tongue, nations can be set against nation; there can be war, famine, death and devastation. Through the tongue, there can be unity, fellowship, peace, and settlements of disputes. We can help and heal one another just as much as we can harm and hurt one another with the words we say. The tongue can be a great blessing if it is used in the way God ordained. The way we speak gives us away, it shows who we are and who we belong to; it shows what kind of person we are. In the world we live in today, unbelievers deliberately use words that cause fights and provoke those around them to anger. As Christians living among them we must be swift to hear, slow to speak, and slow to wrath.  Obscene words, dirty jokes, slander, manipulative speech and irritating words must not come out of our lips, but only what will encourage, unite and edify those around us.
application: Try saying something encouraging to the people around you more often and see how things change.
memory-verse: But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, forbearance, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness and self-control. Against such things there is no law. (Galatians 5:22-23)
prayer: Father, help me to grow in you so the words I say may be used to encourage and bless others.

title: A LIFE OF WORSHIP
passage: "Rejoice evermore. Pray without ceasing. In everything give thanks: for this is the will of God in Christ Jesus concerning you." (1Thessalonians 5:16-18)
content: God wants us to have an attitude of joy, gratitude and prayer at all times, no matter what we’re going through. The text isn’t saying we have to thank God for the bad things and tragedies that come our way in life. It is reminding us that we need to be joyful no matter what is happening because we have Christ, and in Him we can and will overcome any plans the enemy has against us. God doesn’t want us to thank Him for the bad things because he didn’t send them. He is not the creator of evil. We can’t let life’s circumstances make us bitter; we have to rejoice in the Lord. The devil is constantly scheming, one of his preferred schemes is to send something bad into the lives of God’s people and blame it on God. If the devil can get people to believe that the bad things they’re experiencing are happening because of God, it is easier to convince them that God has failed and forsaken them. The devil’s plan is to destroy our faith in God. However, we can overcome these lies of the enemy through prayer and worship. Our prayers should bring praise to His name. We should pray against the attacks of the enemy and ask God to give us the strength to make it through because we have faith that He will bring us out victoriously. Worship is more than music. There are innumerable ways to worship; anytime we give our attention to God is worship. Expressing our love and gratitude to God is worship. You don’t have to be in a church to worship God. Worshiping is moving your focus from your problems and things around you unto God.
application: Whenever you feel down by things happening around you, instead of allowing it to ruin your day use your time to thank God for what He’s done and what you believe He will do and give Him the praise He deserves.
memory-verse: But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, forbearance, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness and self-control. Against such things there is no law. (Galatians 5:22-23)
prayer: Dear God help me to always rejoice in you, no matter what I’m going through. Help me to stand strong in You and not get distracted by the lies of the enemy.

title: PRAYING GOD’S WILL
passage: 14 This is the confidence we have in approaching God: that if we ask anything according to his will, he hears us. 15 And if we know that he hears us—whatever we ask—we know that we have what we asked of him. (1 John 5:14-15)
content: God answers prayers. But there may be times when we may feel as though our prayers are not being answered. There could be several reasons as to why our prayers aren’t being answered. When hardships come, God can sometimes use them as a wake-up call for people going astray. God hates pride and arrogance, but if we humble ourselves in prayer and seek his face and turn away from sin, then He will hear us and deliver us. God wants to answer our prayers; He is willing and ready. But our sins and unrighteousness form a barricade between us and our God. This calls for self-examination. The solution to our problems sometimes might not be breaking yokes or going to deliverance services. Sometimes the solution may be to genuinely repent from our sins. As Christians, our prayers need to be aligned with the will of God. The will of God is so broad, it covers every area of our lives – our happiness, healing, righteousness, etc. Everything we need and will ever need has been willed by God. Praying in accordance to His will doesn’t mean we get to pray for whatever we want and then throw “in Jesus’ name, amen” at the end, hoping that it automatically makes the prayer acceptable. We must pray for the things God wants us to pray about. The more we know about God through Scripture, the better we will have an understanding of how to pray.
application: Search your Bible for the promises God has made you and use them when you pray.
memory-verse: But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, forbearance, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness and self-control. Against such things there is no law. (Galatians 5:22-23)
prayer: Lord, forgive me for my sins and don’t allow them to be a hindrance to my prayers. Let your will be done in my life.

title: GODLY LOVE
passage: “A new command I give you: Love one another. As I have loved you, so you must love one another. 35 By this everyone will know that you are my disciples, if you love one another (John 13: 34- 35).
content: God is love. The purest and truest form of love comes from God; when we love God, we are able to truly love others. We are only able to love others because He loved us first. We were all made in the image of God; He made us to be like Him. As children of God we should be like our Father, so if God is joy, peace, kind, good, faithful, and gentle, then our lives should be a reflection of that. If God is love our lives should reflect that love. When we love ourselves or anything else more than God, love becomes unhealthy and distorted. We begin to define love as whatever we want it to mean. But God loves us so much that He paid the ultimate price and gave us a true example of what love is by sacrificing His only Son, so we can live and have eternal life. This alone should be reason enough to love God. How we love others, especially as Christians, reveals how we love God. Our love for each other is an indication of the place God has in our hearts. In John 13:34, Jesus says “I am giving you a new commandment: Love each other. Just as I have loved you, you should love each other”. This command is important to Christ, so maybe the best thing we can do is take an honest look at the way we love others
application: Sometimes it’s not what you say, it’s how you say it. You can get a better response from someone if you say things with love
memory-verse: But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, forbearance, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness and self-control. Against such things there is no law. (Galatians 5:22-23)
prayer: Lord, I pray that you will teach me to love You with all my heart so that I may love others unconditionally as you love me.

title: WONDER OF WONDERS
passage: “22 Immediately Jesus made the disciples get into the boat and go on ahead of him to the other side, while he dismissed the crowd. 23 After he had dismissed them, he went up on a mountainside by himself to pray. Later that night, he was there alone, 24 and the boat was already a considerable distance from land, buffeted by the waves because the wind was against it. 25 Shortly before dawn Jesus went out to them, walking on the lake. 26 When the disciples saw him walking on the lake, they were terrified. “It’s a ghost,” they said, and cried out in fear. 27 But Jesus immediately said to them: “Take courage! It is I. Don’t be afraid.”28 “Lord, if it’s you,” Peter replied, “tell me to come to you on the water.”29 “Come,” he said. Then Peter got down out of the boat, walked on the water and came toward Jesus. 30 But when he saw the wind, he was afraid and, beginning to sink, cried out, “Lord, save me!” 31 Immediately Jesus reached out his hand and caught him. “You of little faith,” he said, “why did you doubt?” (Matthew 14:22-31)
content: In this passage, Jesus was walking on the lake. The disciples saw Him and were terrified. They thought He was a ghost. He immediately calmed their fears by identifying Himself. Peter asked Jesus, “Lord, if it is really You, tell me to come to You by walking on water.” Jesus said, “All right, come.” Sometimes in life, God will tell us to take a leap of faith. He will even identify Himself as the One leading us. We might even listen and take a step or two out of our comfort zones. However, when we look at the situation through human eyes or listen to the opinion of others, we might falter in following Him. This was the situation with Peter in this passage when Jesus asked him to walk on water. He did it until he looked around him and saw the wind. How many times has Jesus reached out to us asking us to come to Him, give up our current way of life and follow Him? How many times have we “given our lives to God” and said the “sinner’s” prayer only to go back to our old ways after we count the cost of following Christ? How many times have we looked at the Christian journey and given up before we even started? Just like this Bible story, we can only be successful if we keep our eyes on Our Lord and Savior. On our own accord, we cannot be successful on our Christian journey. Jesus is the only One that can help us live a victorious Christian life. When He fills us with His spirit, we can “walk on water” too. We can experience God in unusual ways and grow strong in our faith. Today, I dare you to trust the Master completely in your Christian journey. He will not fail you if you trust Him
application: Do not be afraid to follow His leading once you are sure He is the one speaking. He will help you to fulfill your calling by His great power that is at work within you.
memory-verse: “I am the Lord, the God of all mankind. Is anything too hard for me?” (Jeremiah 32:27)
prayer: Lord, help me to hear when you call me. Let me follow you wholeheartedly without fear when you call me.

title: GONE FISHING
passage: One day as Jesus was standing by the Lake of Gennesaret,[a] the people were crowding around him and listening to the word of God. 2 He saw at the water’s edge two boats, left there by the fishermen, who were washing their nets. 3 He got into one of the boats, the one belonging to Simon, and asked him to put out a little from shore. Then he sat down and taught the people from the boat.4 When he had finished speaking, he said to Simon, “Put out into deep water, and let down the nets for a catch.”5 Simon answered, “Master, we’ve worked hard all night and haven’t caught anything. But because you say so, I will let down the nets.”6 When they had done so, they caught such a large number of fish that their nets began to break. 7 So they signaled their partners in the other boat to come and help them, and they came and filled both boats so full that they began to sink.8 When Simon Peter saw this, he fell at Jesus’ knees and said, “Go away from me, Lord; I am a sinful man!”  (Luke 5:1-8)
content: In life, it is often easy for us to go our own way, after all God gave each of us a measure of wisdom and free will. I remember as a child growing up, I always had my own way of doing things that was different from others. Sometimes, I was disobedient and followed my own way, only to realize the extent of my folly later on when situations got out of my control or I was chastised. In this chapter, Simon was an experienced fisherman. He knew how to fish. His livelihood depended on the fishes he caught. He had worked all night without catching anything. He could have been easily frustrated on such a day. Despite the angst of the day, He listened when Jesus made a request to use his boat. Can you imagine at the end of a long day, having to “waste time” with a stranger when you just want to get home? After Jesus had taken His time to teach from Simon’s boat, He asked him to let down his fishing nets, although his nets were already being cleaned at the end of a long night. Despite the situation, he obeyed Jesus and his life was never the same. In life, we don’t know where or when we will encounter God. It could be on a weary day like Simon did. Because of Simon’s obedience, he experienced God in an unusual way and his life was never the same. Are you like Simon who was willing to obey God despite the odds? Are you a “know it all”? Or are you “too experienced” or “set in your ways” to allow God to work in you and through you? God is able to do more than we think or imagine in our lives, if we allow Him.
application: Be mindful to listen to God always. Do not always rely on your experience, instead trust in God who is able to do all things.
memory-verse: “I am the Lord, the God of all mankind. Is anything too hard for me?” (Jeremiah 32:27)
prayer: Lord, sensitize me to the time and season around me. Help me not to miss my destiny and purpose in my due time and season.

title: A POWERFUL WORD
passage: 46 Once more he visited Cana in Galilee, where he had turned the water into wine. And there was a certain royal official whose son lay sick at Capernaum. 47 When this man heard that Jesus had arrived in Galilee from Judea, he went to him and begged him to come and heal his son, who was close to death.48 “Unless you people see signs and wonders,” Jesus told him, “you will never believe.”49 The royal official said, “Sir, come down before my child dies.”50 “Go,” Jesus replied, “your son will live.”The man took Jesus at his word and departed. 51 While he was still on the way, his servants met him with the news that his boy was living. 52 When he inquired as to the time when his son got better, they said to him, “Yesterday, at one in the afternoon, the fever left him.”53 Then the father realized that this was the exact time at which Jesus had said to him, “Your son will live.” So he and his whole household believed. (Luke 5:46-53)
content: I remember attending a church service last year. During the service, the preacher prophesied that many people would be healed at the service because the power of healing was available, if they believed. He asked anyone who needed healing to ask God for it. I believed the word and was healed of migraines. No one touched me or laid hands on me. I was simply healed because of my faith in God. Many times, we have ailments and we expect ministers of God to lay hands on us before we receive our healing.  It is acceptable to ask them to pray with us, after all the Bible supports it. However, we must realize that God uses His ministers as conduits to release His power. He may choose to heal us anyway He sees fit. The important thing to recognize is that God is the source of our healing. In the story in this passage, Jesus did not lay His hands on the sick son. He did not even visit the house the sick boy was staying in. He simply said a word and the father believed. Sometimes, all we need to do is believe the Word of God that is released, and we will see God move mightily in any area of life we need him to move. I urge you to pray and believe Him today for all your needs, including healing.
application: Declare today that you will trust God to heal you and help you accomplish all things you need in your life, according to His will.
memory-verse: “I am the Lord, the God of all mankind. Is anything too hard for me?” (Jeremiah 32:27)
prayer: Lord, help me to believe your word. Help me not to doubt Your ability to do all things in my life.

title: COLLAPSED WALL
passage: 1Now the gates of Jericho were securely barred because of the Israelites. No one went out and no one came in. 2 Then the LORD said to Joshua, “See, I have delivered Jericho into your hands, along with its king and its fighting men. 3 March around the city once with all the armed men. Do this for six days. 4 Have seven priests carry trumpets of rams’ horns in front of the ark. On the seventh day, march around the city seven times, with the priests blowing the trumpets. 5 When you hear them sound a long blast on the trumpets, have the whole army give a loud shout; then the wall of the city will collapse and the army will go up, everyone straight in. (Joshua 6:1-5)
content: Our God is a God of wonders. I once heard a testimony about a “barren” woman who carried a baby to term without a womb. As I stood listening to the testimony, I was in awe of God because it did not fit the normal pattern of conception. Everyone knows a baby needs a womb to develop. Yet the bouncing baby boy held in the mother’s arms testified to the surreal reality. Similarly, in the story in this passage, it seemed impossible that a loud shout after priests blow their trumpets is all that is needed to break down the fortified wall of a city. The Israelites must have been intimated when God commanded them to head for Jericho. Jericho was a trade metropolis and the oldest walled city in the world at the time. Expecting the city’s walls to collapse after marching around the city for six days, and then waiting until the seventh day before making any move seems like a joke. God did not go through the normal or expected channel, although there were armed men with weapons of war in the group. God could be preparing to deliver your miracle to you. It may come in an unusual way or form; you just have to be open to receive from God, no matter the way He chooses to deliver your breakthrough. Are you open to receiving from God today?
application: Determine in your heart today to be open to God’s miracles, however He plans to accomplish it. Live in expectation of receiving God’s blessing.
memory-verse: “I am the Lord, the God of all mankind. Is anything too hard for me?” (Jeremiah 32:27)
prayer: Lord, let me experience your wonder-working power in my life. Grant me testimonies that will change the faith of others that hear it.

title: MIGHTY IN BATTLE
passage: 10 As Pharaoh approached, the Israelites looked up, and there were the Egyptians, marching after them. They were terrified and cried out to the LORD. 11 They said to Moses, “Was it because there were no graves in Egypt that you brought us to the desert to die? What have you done to us by bringing us out of Egypt? 12 Didn’t we say to you in Egypt, ‘Leave us alone; let us serve the Egyptians’? It would have been better for us to serve the Egyptians than to die in the desert!”13 Moses answered the people, “Do not be afraid. Stand firm and you will see the deliverance the LORD will bring you today. The Egyptians you see today you will never see again. 14 The LORD will fight for you; you need only to be still.”15 Then the LORD said to Moses, “Why are you crying out to me? Tell the Israelites to move on. 16 Raise your staff and stretch out your hand over the sea to divide the water so that the Israelites can go through the sea on dry ground. 17 I will harden the hearts of the Egyptians so that they will go in after them. And I will gain glory through Pharaoh and all his army, through his chariots and his horsemen. 18 The Egyptians will know that I am the LORD when I gain glory through Pharaoh, his chariots and his horsemen.” (Exodus 14: 10-18)
content: I remember being bullied as a child in boarding school in Nigeria. The bully was a year ahead of me in school. She would assign me different punishments for things I did innocently but would claim that they were against school regulations. I remember the day my sister, who was a senior, had “a talk” with her regarding her attitude towards me. She apologized immediately and left me alone once she realized I had someone older and higher in school grade than her, defending me. As Christians, God is our best defense against any contrary power. In this story, the Israelites saw their enemies. These were not “imagined” enemies, but rather real enemies. They saw the enemy and quaked in their shoes at the ferociousness of the enemy. They forgot that the Lord who allowed Pharaoh to let them go in the first place was still on His throne. Despite their fears, God proved Himself mighty to them once again. Indeed, God hardened the hearts of the Egyptians even further and it led to the destruction of their enemies. Sometimes, we will find ourselves in situations where we ask ourselves, “who will fight for us”? Don’t ever forget that the Lord, the maker of Heaven and Earth, the Commander in Chief of Heaven’s armies is on your side. The Lord who has never lost a battle is the one on your side. You can be rest assured that because you have accepted Jesus, you are on the winning side!
application: Trust God to fight for you; be confident in Him and know that He is the ultimate Deliverer who can save you.
memory-verse: “I am the Lord, the God of all mankind. Is anything too hard for me?” (Jeremiah 32:27)
prayer: Fight my battles, O Lord. Give me victory in every battle and challenges facing my life.  Let my enemies make self-destructing mistakes like the armies of Pharaoh.

title: A HANDFUL OF FLOUR AND A LITTLE OLIVE OIL
passage: 12 “As surely as the LORD your God lives,” she replied, “I don’t have any bread—only a handful of flour in a jar and a little olive oil in a jug. I am gathering a few sticks to take home and make a meal for myself and my son, that we may eat it—and die.” 13 Elijah said to her, “Don’t be afraid. Go home and do as you have said. But first make a small loaf of bread for me from what you have and bring it to me, and then make something for yourself and your son. 14 For this is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: ‘The jar of flour will not be used up and the jug of oil will not run dry until the day the LORD sends rain on the land.’” (1 Kings 17:12-14)
content: I am always amazed when I read this Bible story. I often ask myself why God sent Prophet Elijah to the widow of Zarephath. Why didn’t He send Elijah to a rich man, a king or someone with a lot of money? The prophet Elijah had not been living well since hiding from King Ahab. God told him to go to Zarephath. Prior to going to Zarephath, his meals were provided miraculously by ravens. One would think that when he left his current situation, it would be to a muchimproved status. However, God sent him to a poor widow. Not just any widow but one who had lost all hope. The widow was going to make a meal for herself and her son so that they may eat and die. Our God has a sense of humor. He used the need of prophet Elijah to save the widow and her son. Because the widow obeyed the prophet, she experienced divine provision. Sometimes, we might have to give out of our great need to a cause God is compelling us to support. Other times we might have to pay our tithe and offering while knowing we don’t have enough money to pay the rest of our monthly bills. Our God is a great provider. He knows our needs and He will provide for us accordingly. The Lord who used five loaves of bread and two fishes to feed a multitude, the God who fed prophet Elijah through ravens and the Savior who saved the widow of Zarephath and her son from death is able to supply all your needs today. Won’t you trust Him? He will cause all things to work together for your good.
application: Be faithful in giving to the kingdom of God through your tithes and offering, as commanded in the Bible. As you obey God, depend on Him to meet your monetary and non-monetary needs.
memory-verse: “I am the Lord, the God of all mankind. Is anything too hard for me?” (Jeremiah 32:27)
prayer: Lord, I come before you today with all my needs. I pray that you will provide for all my needs according to your riches in glory through Christ Jesus.

title: THE LORD THAT ANSWERS BY FIRE
passage: 20 So Ahab sent word throughout all Israel and assembled the prophets on Mount Carmel. 21 Elijah went before the people and said, “How long will you waver between two opinions? If the LORD is God, follow him; but if Baal is God, follow him.”But the people said nothing. 22 Then Elijah said to them, “I am the only one of the LORD’s prophets left, but Baal has four hundred and fifty prophets. 23 Get two bulls for us. Let Baal’s prophets choose one for themselves, and let them cut it into pieces and put it on the wood but not set fire to it. I will prepare the other bull and put it on the wood but not set fire to it. 24 Then you call on the name of your god, and I will call on the name of the LORD. The god who answers by fire—he is God.”Then all the people said, “What you say is good.” (1 King 18: 20-24)
content: I remember when I was trying to make a career choice. I considered different careers in the healthcare field. I thought about the pros and cons of different careers. I also thought about the income and lifestyle I wanted for my future. In the end, I went with the career I had the best aptitude for and felt God was leading me to choose. Ahab, son of Omri, a king in Israel did more evil in the Lord’s sight than any of the kings before him. He did more to arouse God’s anger than any of the other kings of Israel. He also married Jezebel, began to worship Baal and set up a temple and altar for Baal. In this story, Elijah asked the people to make a choice. Follow God, their maker, or follow Baal. He tried to convince them of the invincibility of the Lord God over Baal. Elijah prepared a bull and laid it on a wooden altar. The prophets of Baal did the same. Elijah dug a water-filled trench around the altar and called on the Lord to prove His supremacy over Baal. Of course, God reigned supreme. You might be asking yourself the same questions. Which gods or God should I serve? There are many religions today, but the right choice is obvious. The Bible is clear on this topic. Jesus is the way, the truth and life. He is our only access to God. Accept Him today.
application: Pray to God to continue to reveal Himself to you and remove every doubt that the enemy brings to your mind
memory-verse: “I am the Lord, the God of all mankind. Is anything too hard for me?” (Jeremiah 32:27)
prayer: Lord, reveal yourself to me. In any way I have doubts about your supremacy, convince me and help me to trust you more.

title: FORGIVENESS IS FOR YOU
passage: 31 Let all bitterness and wrath and anger and clamor and slander be put away from you, along with all malice. 32 Be kind to one another, tenderhearted, forgiving one another, as God in Christ forgave you. (Ephesians 4:31 - 32)
content:
When we choose to forgive someone, we’re wiping the slate clean, pardoning them and letting go of the desire to enact vengeance. There are times when we don’t want to forgive people who have wronged us, but not forgiving others makes us bitter and angry. By forgiving others we free ourselves emotionally and spiritually. We can use forgiveness as a way of showing God that we trust Him to heal us emotionally. Letting go of anger and hurt can help keep you calm and even improve your health, but most importantly forgiving others is a way to receive God’s forgiveness for our own sins. 
As we forgive those who have wronged us we also have to remember that forgiveness is not a free pass for others to take advantage of us. Forgiveness does not condone the offense nor does it mean that the offense never happened; it’s simply letting it go. Even though you’re not excusing the offense you can choose to not be consumed by the anger and hurt. We have to trust God to avenge us and remember that there will come a time when we will no longer feel the pain so deeply. We ourselves aren’t perfect so we should be empathetic. Just like we’d like to be forgiven, we should forgive others for their mistakes as well.
application: Remember that forgiveness is more beneficial for you and Jesus you to forgive all the time no matter how many times you’ve been wronged.
memory-verse: Riches and honor come from you, and you are the ruler of everything. Power and might are in your hand, and it is in Your hand to make great and to give strength to all. (1 Chronicles 29:12)
prayer: Dear God, help me to forgive those who have wronged me regardless of my feelings. I’m letting this go and I set myself free for your healing. Thank you for forgiving me as I have forgiven them. Amen

title: THE MOTIVE TO GIVE
passage: 7 Each of you should give what you have decided in your heart to give, not reluctantly or under compulsion, for God loves a cheerful giver. (2 Corinthians 9:7)
content: When it comes to giving, motivation is everything. There are many wrong motives for giving.  We are always told “Give, and it will be given to you…” this scripture in Luke 6:38 is often used to motivate people to give, but Jesus is not promising us that if we give we will receive more in return. Giving to get is the wrong motivation. Jesus wants us to be generous givers because the giver is more blessed than those who receive.  He may not bless you financially for your offerings, but he might give you an unexpected gift, a new car or good health.  Another wrong reason to give is so we can be praised and honored by men. Giving should be an act done in secret before God (Matt 6:4). With that being said, we should give because God has given to us. He gave us is Son, He has blessed us spiritually, everything we have was given to us by Him and He always provides for us. God has blessed us abundantly so we should give back to Him generously and cheerfully. But God cares about our attitude of giving as well as what we give. Giving also helps us to be compassionate people. Our lives today require so much, there are so many needs that have to be fulfilled. It can be easier to focus on ourselves and not give at all. It’s not possible to help every person in need all around the world but we should do all we can to show compassion in the name of Christ. Giving teaches us to find our security in God and to rely on Him for our needs. If you give, God promises to supply your needs.
application: The definition of ‘Give’ is “to freely transfer the possession of (something) to (someone)”. So if God has so freely given us everything we have, we should have no problem showing our gratitude to Him by giving back.
memory-verse: Riches and honor come from you, and you are the ruler of everything. Power and might are in your hand, and it is in your hand to make great and to give strength to all. (1 Chronicles 29:12)
prayer: Lord I thank you for all that you have given to me. I pray that you will give me a heart that loves to give and serve others with what you have so graciously given to me. Amen

title: BENEFITS OF A HUMBLE LIFE
passage: 6 Humble yourselves, therefore, under the mighty hand of God so that at the proper time he may exalt you, 7 casting all your anxieties on him, because he cares for you. (1 Peter 5:6-7)
content: Humility is essential to our growth as believers.  We can’t truly make spiritual progress until we fully understand who we are in Christ.  God is Holy and we are sinners in need of His grace. If we remember this it will help our walk with Christ and in the way we treat others. As humans humility doesn’t come easily. Our flesh craves the confidence that comes from pride. The world is constantly telling us to put ourselves first and the enemy wants nothing more for us than to fall into a world of arrogance and pride. Thankfully there are some things we can do to keep ourselves in check. Reading and actually studying the Bible reminds us that God is holy and we are not. The beginning of humility is seeing God for who He is and seeking the forgiveness that only He can give. The Bible is filled with messages that give us the hope that only the Gospel brings. We have to make time to study, meditate and memorize the Bible. We must also learn how important our local church is to our walk with Christ, especially since there are so many commandments in the Bible we can’t obey unless we are a part of a local body. Serving others in our local church can help us grow in humility. If you chose to work in the nursery, help feed the homeless or simply listening to a fellow believer share their hardships, it’s going to help you to think outside of yourself. Helping others is a reminder that we aren’t the center of the universe and we weren’t created to live for ourselves. We should also make time for prayer.  The Bible commands us to humble ourselves and cast our worries and anxieties on Him. When we pray we are acknowledging that God is God, we are asking Him for what we don’t have on our own and for what only He can give.
application: Take time out of your busy schedule to help and or encourage someone in need.
memory-verse: Riches and honor come from you, and you are the ruler of everything. Power and might are in your hand, and it is in your hand to make great and to give strength to all.  (1 Chronicles 29:12)
